bibl.title: Letter from M.S. Lombard to [Hugh S. Cumming], September 18, 1922

div1.p: Lombard reports on a possible yellow fever case involving the death of a Spanish seaman. He includes clinical and pathological reports and describes treatment of the vessel and crew.

div1.head: Letter from M.S. Lombard to [Hugh S. Cumming], September 18, 1922
div1.opener:
Re: Diagnosis Miguel Vicens.
Mobile Quarantine
Fort Morgan, Alabama.
CCD
Fort Morgan, Ala.,
September 18, 1922.
The Surgeon General,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Washington, D. C.
Sir:
div1.p:
With reference to radiogram sent from this office
September 14, 1922, I have the honor to submit the
following report of circumstances connected with the
death on board the American Schooner “WILLIAM E. BURNHAM”
at 8:55 P. M., September 13, 1922.

The Schooner arrived in quarantine at 8:45 A. M.,
September 14, 1922, from Freetown, Sierra Leone W. Africa,
calling at Paramaribo and Mungo, Dutch Guiana, and was
promptly boarded.

The vessel left the United States from Gulfport,
Miss., for West Africa, in April, 1922. It departed
from Freetown Sierra Leone for the United States on
June 25, 1922, via Paramaribo, Dutch Quiana, arriving
thereat August 6, 1922. From this last named port, the
schooner went up river to Mungo August 12, 1922, loaded
bauxite ore, returned to Paramaribo and sailed therefrom
on August 23, 1922.

P- Aug 6-12
Mungo
P (left) 23
Sek-Spt 6

On arrival at Paramaribo, the vessel had to wait
about one week before going up river, for the reason
that the stream is so narrow, that only one vessel at
a time can navigate it, and had to wait for another
schooner to come down. This indicates that all this
time, there was an intimate relation with shore. The
vessel was in Mungo about one week and consumed five
other days on the trip down. No night navigation was
undertaken in the river.

On investigation of circumstances surrounding the
death of Seaman Miguel Vicens, a Spanish subject, 47 years
of age, the following clinical history was detailed by
the Captain and members of the crew.

The deceased first notified the Captain of his
illness on September 6th, and complained of headache,
pains all over the body and high fever. He remained
ill with fever until the 9th, when he felt better.
On September 10th, he felt worse and the fever reached
105, which remained high till death occurred the evening
of September 13, 1922. He died in a comatose condition.
It was ascertained that the deceased was ill a few days
prior to the sudden onset on September 6th, that he
vomited and had a chill, that he complained of loss of
appetite, constipation, sore throat, that his eyes were
bright and that the fever did not terminate at any stage
as is the case in Malaria.
Death 7 day

Six other members of the crew at various times had
fever from the time the vessel departed from Mungo and
subsequent to leaving Paramaribo, but made were in-
capaciteted from duty, nor did the fever last more than
three days in any of these cases.

The body was brought in quarantine therefore available
for necropsy which was held on board the schooner the same
date at 10:00 A.M., and the following pathological lesions
were recorded:
Entire body jaundiced.

Lungs: Hypostatic conjestion due to recumbent
posture.

Pericardium: Slight amount of clear pericardial
fluid.

Heart: About normal size, flaccid, no apparent
degeneration.

Liver: Slightly enlarged pale-yellow, indicating
fatty degeneration.

Gall Bladder: Distended and filled with bile,
some transudation of bile staining
neighboring organs. No stones found in
the organ, or in any of the biliary
passages, no perforation or rupture.

Stomach: About normal size, containing a
yellowish fluid, apparently bile
stained.
Appendix: Retrococeal and adherent.

Spleen: Enlarged to approximately twice
normal size very friable and on
section the spleen substance bulged
out having the consistency of a
solid or semi-solid blood clot,
no rupture or other injury detected.

Kidneys: Left enlarged, considerable larger
than the right.
Other Organs: Hegative.

Blood smears made and about five ounces of urine
obtained by catherization, which an examination at this
station's laboratory at 2:00 P. M., recorded the following:

Blood: Negative for Malaria, increase in
mononuclears.

The clinical history as obtained from the Captain
and crew of the “WILLIAM E. BURNHAM”, indicated that the
death in this case was due to a severe infection of some
sort, closely coinciding with that found in yellow fever,
except, as to incubation period, which is greater than
the generally admitted six days. It is possible however,
that the case was one of walking yellow fever originally
or that an infected mosquito may have gone aboard the
vessel in Paramaribo or vicinity and that it ripened and
subsequently infected the case.

The post mortem findings of jaundice, fatty liver,
excessive albuminuria, soft enlarged spleen and the
absence of malaria parasites in the blood, point clearly
to yellow fever.

The case was considered as yellow fever, but no
efforts were spared to prove something else.

Vessel fumigated and vessel and crew detained for
six days.

Blood examinations of all humans on board were
negative for malaria. Temperature of all taken twice
daily.

On the written request of the Captain, copy inclosed,
the body of Miguel Vicens, was interned in the quarantine
reservation at 5:00 P. M., September 14, 1922.
div1.closer:
Respectfully submitted M. S. Lombard,
P. A. Surgeon in Charge. COPY
